The practice became illegal in 1970 but still happens across the United States. The PAST Act would remedy this problem by closing existing loopholes in federal law, increasing penalties for abusers, and strengthening the inspection process.

Last night, I spoke in support of the PAST Act.
 
This bipartisan bill would end the inhumane practice of horse soaring, the process in which trainers deliberately inflict pain on Tennessee Walking Horses’ hooves to give them a competitive advantage in horse shows. pic.twitter.com/6GlKvoIwJm

The House just passed the LEGION Act! This bill would open up @AmericanLegion membership to ALL honorably discharged veterans since World War II.

In the past, only veterans who had served during periods of declared hostilities were eligible to become members.
This deal would not be acceptable in a North Carolina family’s budget, and it certainly isn't in the federal government’s.  (3/3)

Congress continues to be willfully blind to the fiscal peril that faces us. We have $22 trillion of debt. Our debt to GDP ratio is more than 100 percent. Within the next five years, taxpayers will be forced to spend more to service our debt than on national defense.  (2/3)

I will be voting against the two-year budget deal. 

I did not come to Congress to be an enabler of Washington’s spending addiction. This budget deal not only suspends the debt ceiling, it hikes federal spending by over $300 billion.  (1/3)
